OpeNoise is an app aimed at the measurement of real-time sound pressure level.

This app is not intended for professional use, it does not necessarily guarantee an accurate noise measurement. 
Since each device has a different response to noise, a comparison with a professional noise level meter in the measurement dynamic range is required. 
The utilization of the app requires adequate technical knowledge and skill; an extemporary measurement might not be correct.
For more information, please refer to the device calibration and dynamic range specifications in the Tutorial section.

- Real-time A-weighted sound pressure level measurement 
- Minimum and maximum level
- Third octave and FFT analysis
- Data saving in text file
- Sampling time setting
- Calibration

Gain setting is necessary to use this app correctly. To set the Gain you have to check measured data with the actual value.\nBe careful that Gain setting is lost after each update (and reset to 0 dB).

This app can save noise data in a log file. 
Push the 'START LOG' button to start saving data. 
Files are saved in the directory 'openoise' allocated in the local memory (not in external SD).

TAKING A MEASUREMENT 
Noise measurement starts antomatically opening OpeNoise. To stop the measurement push 'Exit' in the main menù or the 'Back' button of the device (pushing the 'Home' button the measurement keeps running in background). Push 'RESET' to start a new measurement and reset all levels. 
 
CALIBRATING THE DEVICE 
Since each device has a different response to noise, it is necessary a calibration. 
To calibrate the device, a comparison with a professional noise level meter in the measurement dynamic range is required. On the basis of the comparison, set the decibel value to add or subtract (with a positive or negative value, i.e. '8.9' or '-8.9') in order to obtain the same level in the Settings. 
Be careful that Calibration could be reset to 0 dB after each app update. 
 
DYNAMIC RANGE 
Although calibrated, the devices are not able to correctly measure beyond a certain dynamic range (above a maximum value and below a minimum value). After having calibrated the system, it is necessary to check these two values, possibly through a comparison with a professional noise level meter. Beyond these threshold, measurements might not be reliable. 
 
DATA SAVING 
This option is activated selecting in the Settings menu the 'Advanced with data saving' interface. Thus, it's displayed the 'SAVE' button which can be pushed to save data in a text file (audio is not recorded). Files are saved in the directory 'openoise' allocated in the local memory (not in external SD) and can be opened in the 'Saved data' section or with another app. 
 
PLOTS 
In the Simple interface it is showed only a plot displaying minimum, instantaneous and maximum levels. In the Advanced interface three plots in this order are showed: 
 - Global levels time history 
 - Third octave frequency spectrum and global levels 
 - FFT frequency spectrum 
Tap the plot to show the next one.

dB 
It is the parameter for the sound pressure level measurement. 
 
dB(A) 
It is the parameter for the sound pressure level measurement weighted in frequency according to the response of the human ear ('A' ponderation). 
 
LMin 
Minimum level since the measurement starts, in dB. 
 
LAMin 
Minimum level since the measurement starts, in dB(A). 
 
LMax 
Maximum level since the measurement starts, in dB. 
 
LAMax 
Maximum level since the measurement starts, in dB(A). 
 
Leq(0.5-1-2 s) 
Sound pressure level of the last time set (0.5, 1 o 2 seconds), in dB. 
 
LAeq(0.5-1-2 s) 
Sound pressure level of the last time set (0.5, 1 o 2 seconds), in dB(A). 
 
Leq(t) 
Sound pressure level since the measurement starts, in dB. 
 
LAeq(t) 
Sound pressure level since the measurement starts, in dB(A). 
 
GLOBAL LEVEL 
Sound pressure level calculated with all the frequency spectrum. 
 
SPECTRUM 
Frequency distribution of the sound pressure level. 
 
THIRD OCTAVE 
Rapresentation of the frequency spectrum in a constant percentage bandwidth. The data are showed in dB. 
 
FFT (Fast Fourier Transform) 
Technique for calculating the frequency spectrum with a constant bandwidth. In OpeNoise the bandwidth is 25 Hz. The data are showed in dB and dB(A).
